intro: Lophotocarpus guayanensis var. lappula, commonly known as the Guayana lappula, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, umbellate flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as forest understories, and is adapted to tropical and subtropical climates. Its botanical features include a slender, branched stem and aromatic foliage, which contribute to its ecological and potential medicinal significance.
